Alberts. This sum was not paid into the Company's cash by C. Alberts. On the previous day he received a cable from India stating that his wife was dangerously ill and applied to us on 1st December in writing for one month's compassionate leave. This was granted on the 2nd December 1947 and he left for India on the 4th December 1947. The cheque, which Xs in the possession of the Eastern Bank Ltd., was signed and endorsed by Mr.B.H.Lermitte and further endorsed by C. Alberts. On 28th December 1947 he wrote from Haroon Building 3rd floor, Parel, Bombay, stating that he had 'come down to Bombay and will sail for Bahrain by the 1st available steamer after the 4th January 1948'. We had written to him at his previous address on 28th December 1947 informing him that we had instructed our agents, Messrs. Anglo-Iranian Oil Co. Ltd., Bombay, regarding his return to Bahrain. As we had no news of him, we wired A.I.O.C., Bombay, on 24th January 194 8 and received the following reply on 2nd February 1948: '12 Your BB8 Alberts not reported nor any information received will clarify and inform you' The above telegram crossed ours of the same date reading as follows: 'BBll Our BB8 and PMP/5462 please telegraph date Alberts reported you and date expected sail' It was not until the 29th February 1948 that the loss of the cash was discovered when our Qatar Accounts Depart ment were checking the Bank passbook with their cash book. The amount of Rs.65000 was drawn, we believe, by Alberts producing a copy of a previous letter authorising the withdrawal of a sum of Rso 165000, and it is to be presumed that the amount on the copy of that letter had been altered together with the date. physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in chronological order from the front to the rear of the file. Circled serial numbers written in crayon (red for incoming, blue for outgoing correspondence) refer to entries in the notes at the rear of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence commences at 1 on the front cover and terminates at 21 on the back cover. The numbers are written in pencil and appear in the top right hand corner of the recto page of each folio. Foliation anomaly: 3, 3A.

mods.abstract: The file relates to the disappearance and issue of a warrant for the arrest of Christopher Alberts, a cashier with Petroleum Development (Qatar) Limited, following the misappropriation of a sum of 65,000 rupees belonging to the Company. The papers include correspondence from Petroleum Development (Qatar) Limited; Petroleum Concessions Limited; the Political Agent, Bahrain (Cornelius James Pelly); the office of the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf; and the Government of India. The papers also include discussion of the question of whether the Fugitive Offenders Act 1881 could be applied if, as seemed likely, Alberts had fled to Goa, March 1948; and a copy of the warrant for Alberts's arrest, signed by Pelly, 6 April 1948.Note that the 'D' in Alberts's name in the file title appears to be an error.
